results.title: And yet it moves
results.brief_description: This film provides a look at how animators use their imagination; it also shows the materials they use. The film is divided into sections which show the creation of brief but effective story lines or commentaries in various media. Plasticine becomes a gracefully moving woman; another blob becomes a comic singer complete with cape; an egg revolves, bounces and catches fish.

results.title: And what about sugar ?
results.brief_description: This film glosses over the adverse effects of the consumption of sugar by implying that sugar is good for you in controlled doses, and that proper tooth care, rather than diet will prevent dental cavities. No other credits available.

results.title: And we're going. 4. To Toledo = I ya vamos. 4. A Toledo
results.creator_credit: Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Joshua Tree Productions
results.brief_description: A Spanish language film. Provides some cultural background of Spain and points out to the students the difference between Spanish spoken by Spanish Americans and Spanish spoken in Spain.

results.title: And they named it Holland
results.creator_credit: Carillon Films and Gerard J. Raucamp
results.brief_description: Provides aerial views of Holland, without commentary. Illustrates the variety of environment contrasting old and new, urban and rural, highlighting the diversity of life in a small and densely populated country.

results.title: And then there were four
results.creator_credit: Roland Reed, Roland Reed Productions and Frank Strayer
results.brief_description: Hollywood actor, James Stewart, narrates the story of five people leaving for work in the morning. None of these people are reckless drivers, but we know in advance that one of them will die on the road that day. When one fails to return at evening, we know he is the victim of a road accident. This film is a dramatic lesson in traffic law observance. An epilogue provides relevance to Australian road safety statistics for the time.

results.title: And then there was one
results.creator_credit: Oswald Skilbeck, Verity Films, Film Producers Guild and Eric Marquis
results.brief_description: Deals with the subject of depression, arguing that its symptoms are frequently overlooked. Illustrated with four examples: an overburdened salesman, a young mother unable to cope, a female factory worker with a repetitive job, and an older office worker whose symptoms are not recognised. Intended mainly for general practitioners. Written by Christine Netscher, photographed by Joe Ambor and edited by Ted Hunter. This film won the Silver Award (Category A) at the B.M.A film competition in 1966.

results.title: And then there was glass
results.brief_description: This documentary shows how glass is made. It gives an impression of the modern (1969) automatic machinery producing the molten material which is to be blown or pressed into the required shapes. It also shows the varied types of glass, and the uses to which they are put.
results.description: This documentary shows how glass is made. It gives an impression of the modern (1969) automatic machinery producing the molten material which is to be blown or pressed into the required shapes. It also shows the varied types of glass, and the uses to which they are put.

results.title: And their ghosts may be heard
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones, Film Australia and Keith Gow
results.brief_description: In 1893 a boat load of Australian bush workers and tradesmen sailed halfway around the world to Paraguay to establish a New Australia colony in which the old Australian principles of equality and mateship would at last be realised. The film follows the footsteps of those pioneers from a strike-torn sheep country into the heart of Paraguay, landlocked into the heart of South America, where the survivors of the great experiment still live today, dreaming in exile of the gum trees in a far-off land their ancestors chose to leave but could never forget. Presented by Caroline Jones and sourced from the book by Gavin Souter “A Peculiar people: the Australians in Paraguay”. English/Spanish language.

results.title: And the moon dances = Bulan terusuk ilalang
results.creator_credit: PT Genta Nusa Dwipantara, S E T Film Workshop and Garin Nugroho
results.brief_description: Shot in Solo, director Garin Nugroho’s hometown, ‘And the Moon Dances’ is a rich visual and aural feast of feudal Javanese culture. Ilalang, a young music student, comes to Solo for an attachment at the local dance and culture school. This is where he meets Bulan, a girl who has just returned from America. However, the love between them remains unrequited as Ilalang is trying to deal with the trauma he suffered in childhood at the hands of his father. The paradox of the Javanese culture is the central theme of this film. To quote from director Nugroho, the Javanese culture ‘could be beautiful and soft at one time and violent the next’. Technically, this film surpasses its predecessors. The colours are rich and the sound of the Gamelan, omnipresent throughout the film, superbly showcased. This film received the FIPRESCI Award at the 1996 Berlin International Film Festival. Cast includes Ratna Paquita, Wiwiek Handawiyah, Ki Sutarman. In Bahasa Indonesia with English subtitles.
